revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1675|music}}
The year '''1675 in music''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *[[Agostino Steffani]] is appointed court organist at Munich. *[[Johann Krieger]] performs at Vienna, and is rewarded by [[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor]].
==Published popular music== *
==Classical music== *[[Christian Geist]] – ''Laudet Deum mea'' *[[Guillaume-Gabriel Nivers]] – ''3e livre d'orgue des huit tons de l'église'', organ collection *[[Alessandro Stradella]] – ''Qual prodigio è ch'io miri'', a [[serenade|serenata]]
==[[Opera]]== *[[Matthew Locke (composer)|Matthew Locke]] – ''Psyche''
==Births== *[[July 12]] – [[Evaristo Felice Dall'Abaco]], Italian composer (died 1742) *''date unknown'' – [[Louis de La Coste]], composer (died 1750) *''probable'' **[[Giovanni Porta]], opera composer (died 1755) **Tommaso Redi, composer
==Deaths== *[[March 23]] – [[Anthoni van Noordt]], Dutch organist and composer (born 1619) *[[September 5]] – [[Carlos Patiño]], composer (born 1600) *[[October 29]] – [[Andreas Hammerschmidt]], organist and composer (born c.1611) *[[November 14]] – [[Johannes Khuen]], priest, poet and composer (born 1606) * ''date unknown'' – [[Wojciech Bobowski]], Polish Ottoman musician (born 1610)
[[Category:1675 in music| ]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{Year nav topic5|2016|art}}
The year '''2016 in [[art]]''' involves various significant events.
==Events== *March - The [[Met Breuer]] opens in the former home of the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/03/04/arts/music/vijay-iyer-and-mark-turner-help-open-the-met-breuer.html?_r=0&referer=https://www.google.com/|title=Vijay Iyer and Mark Turner Help Open the Met Breuer|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:Whitney Museum of American Art.JPG|thumb|right|267px|The Whitney Museum of American Art's former (1966–2014) home on Madison Avenue; the [[Marcel Breuer]]-designed building was leased by the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] beginning in 2016. It is now known as the Met Breuer.]] *[[July 28]] - The re-discovery of [[Albrecht Dürer]]'s engraving ''[[Mary with Infant Jesus]]'' previously considered lost since World War II is reported.<ref name="blou">{{cite web | url =http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1468921/flea-market-find-alsatian-collector-returns-long-lost-durer|title=Flea Market Find: Alsatian Collector Returns Long Lost Dürer Engraving to Stuttgart Staatsgalerie|publisher=[[Louise Blouin Media]]| date=July 28, 2016| accessdate =August 8, 2016}}</ref> The engraving was noticed in good condition at a flea market in [[Sarrebourg]] and returned to [[Staatsgalerie Stuttgart]].<ref name="blou"/> *[[September 30]] - The recovery of two paintings by [[Vincent van Gogh]], ''[[Seascape at Scheveningen]]'' and ''[[Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church in Nuenen]]'', stolen in 2002, is announced.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/en/news-and-press/press-releases/two-stolen-van-gogh-paintings-recovered-after-14-years|title=Two stolen Van Gogh paintings recovered after 14 years|publisher=Van Gogh Museum| date=30 September 2016| accessdate =30 September 2016}}</ref> *[[December 19]] - The [[List of ambassadors of Russia to Turkey|Russian Ambassador to Turkey]]; [[Andrei Karlov]] is shot dead at [[point-blank-range]] in an act of [[Assassination of Andrei Karlov|political assassination]] (by Mevlüt Mert Altıntaş who is believed to have been an off duty Turkish police officer) while giving a speech at an exhibition of Russian photographs at the [[Çankaya, Ankara (district)|Çankaya]] Contemporary Arts Center in [[Ankara]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/russian-ambassador-to-turkey-wounded-in-ankara-shooting-attack/ar-AAlKgzn?OCID=ansmsnnews11# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-12-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221121247/http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/russian-ambassador-to-turkey-wounded-in-ankara-shooting-attack/ar-AAlKgzn?OCID=ansmsnnews11# |archive-date=2016-12-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/world/europe/russia-ambassador-shot-ankara-turkey.html|title=Russian Ambassador to Turkey Is Assassinated in Ankara|publisher=}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== *[[January 20]] until [[April 17]] - "In the Lion's Den: Daniel MacDonald, [[Ireland]] and Empire" at [[Ireland’s Great Hunger Museum]] at [[Quinnipiac University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/02/19/arts/design/the-artist-who-dared-to-paint-irelands-great-famine.html?referer=http://ighm.org/|title=The Artist Who Dared to Paint Ireland’s Great Famine|publisher=}}</ref> *[[February 5]] until [[April 27]] - [[Peter Fischli]] [[David Weiss (artist)|David Weiss]]: How to Work Better" at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/exhibition/peter-fischli-david-weiss-how-to-work-better|title=Peter Fischli David Weiss: How to Work Better|date=2 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[February 18]] until [[May 15]] - "[[Georgia OKeefe|O'Keefe]], [[Florine Stettheimer|Stettheimer]], [[Helen Torr|Torr]], [[Marguerite Zorach|Zorach]]: Women Modernists in New York" at the [[Norton Museum of Art]] in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.norton.org/exhibitions|title=Norton Museum of Art - Current Exhibition|website=www.norton.org}}</ref> *[[February 18]] until [[June 13]] - "[[Edvard Munch|Munch]] and Expressionism" at the [[Neue Galerie]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neuegalerie.org/content/munch-and-expressionism-0|title=Neue Galerie New York|first=Neue Galerie New|last=York|publisher=}}</ref> *[[March 18]] until [[September 4]] - "Unfinished: Thoughts Left Visible" at the [[Met Breuer]] in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/unfinished# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-04-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407234307/http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/unfinished# |archive-date=2016-04-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[March 2]] until [[June 5]] - "[[Van Dyck]]: The Anatomy of Portraiture" at the [[Frick collection]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frick.org/exhibitions/van_dyck#sthash.Kun5OgD8.dpuf|title=Past Exhibition - The Frick Collection|website=www.frick.org}}</ref> *[[March 23]] until [[July 10]] - "[[Umberto Boccioni]]: Genio and Memoria (Genius and Memory)" at the [[Palazzo Reale]] in [[Milan, Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milanmuseumguide.com/umberto-boccioni-genio-memoria/|title=Umberto Boccioni exhibition at Palazzo Reale Milan|date=5 March 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[March 26]] until February 1, 2017 - "[[Alex Da Corte]]: Free Roses" at [[Mass MOCA]] in [[North Adams, Massachusetts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artsy.net/show/mass-moca-alex-da-corte-free-roses|title=Alex Da Corte: Free Roses - MASS MoCA - Artsy|website=www.artsy.net}}</ref> *[[April 27]] until [[June 19]] - "Andra Ursuta: Alps" at the [[New Museum]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/andra-ursuta-alps|title=Andra Ursuta: Alps|website=www.newmuseum.org}}</ref> *[[May 7]] until [[November 27]] - "A [[Third Gender]]: Beautiful Youths in Japanese Prints" (curated by Asato Ikeda) at the [[Royal Ontario Museum]] in [[Toronto, Ontario]], Canada then traveled to the [[Japan Society (Manhattan)|Japan Society]] in New York City from March 10 until June 11, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rom.on.ca/en/exhibitions-galleries/exhibitions/a-third-gender-beautiful-youths-in-japanese|title=A Third Gender: Beautiful Youths in Japanese Prints|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japansociety.org/page/programs/gallery/a-third-gender |title=A Third Gender: Gallery: Programs |publisher=Japan Society |date= |accessdate=2018-09-20}}</ref> *[[May 27]] until [[September 7]] - "[[Moholy-Nagy]]: Future Present" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in [[New York City]].<ref>at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York City.</ref> *[[June 10]] until [[September 25]] - "[[Stuart Davis (painter)|Stuart Davis]]: In Full Swing" at the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/StuartDavis|title=Stuart Davis: In Full Swing|website=whitney.org}}</ref> *[[June 18]] until April 16, 2017 - "[[Tony Oursler]]: Imponderable" at [[MOMA]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.moma.org/2016/04/tony-oursler-imponderable/|title=Tony Oursler: Imponderable|website=press.moma.org}}</ref> *[[September 1]] until [[October 23]] - ''[[Bjork]] [[Björk Digital|Digital]]'' at [[Somerset House]] in [[London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.somersethouse.org.uk/visual-arts/bjork-digital|title=Björk Digital|date=7 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[September 2]] until January 8, 2017 - "[[Hans Memling]]: Portraiture, Piety, and a Reunited Altarpiece at the [[Morgan Library]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themorgan.org/exhibitions/hans-memling|title=Hans Memling: Portraiture, Piety, and a Reunited Altarpiece|date=5 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[September 16]] until January 2, 2017 - "[[Carmen Herrera]]: Lines of Sight" at the Whitney Museum of American Art.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitney.org/Exhibitions/CarmenHerrera|title=Carmen Herrera: Lines of Sight|website=whitney.org}}</ref> *[[September 30]] until January 29, 2017 - "Los Angeles to New York: [[Virginia Dwan|Dwan Gallery]], 1959-1971" at the [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington D.C.]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/18/arts/design/virginia-dwan-a-jet-age-medici-gets-her-due.htmlaction=click&contentCollection=Art%20%26%20Design&module=RelatedCoverage&region=EndOfArticle&pgtype=article]{{Dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/exhibitions/2016/from-los-angeles-to-new-york-dwan-gallery.html|title=Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery, 1959–1971|website=www.nga.gov}}</ref> *[[October 7]] until January 16, 2017 - "[[Valentin de Boulogne]]: Beyond [[Caravaggio]]" at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/valentin-de-boulogne |title=Valentin de Boulogne: Beyond Caravaggio | The Metropolitan Museum of Art |publisher=Metmuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2018-09-20}}</ref> *October 7 until January 11, "[[Agnes Martin]]" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City.<ref>https://www.guggenheim.org/exhibition/agnes-martin></ref> *[[October 19]] until February 20, 2017 - "[[Max Beckmann]] in New York" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/max-beckmann# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-11-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104024928/http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/max-beckmann# |archive-date=2016-11-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[October 25]] - January 29, 2017 - "[[Kerry James Marshall]] : Mastry" at the Met Breuer in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/kerry-james-marshall# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-12-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221010532/http://www.metmuseum.org/press/exhibitions/2016/kerry-james-marshall# |archive-date=2016-12-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[October 26]] - January 15, 2017 - "[[Pipilotti Rist]]: Pixel Forest" at the New Museum in New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newmuseum.org/exhibitions/view/pipilotti-rist-pixel-forest|title=Pipilotti Rist: Pixel Forest|website=www.newmuseum.org}}</ref> *[[November 21]] until March 16, 2017 - "[[Francis Picabia]]: Our Heads Are Round so Our Thoughts Can Change Direction" at MOMA in New York City.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/18/arts/design/francis-picabia-the-playboy-prankster-of-moderism.html?_r=0|title=Francis Picabia, the Playboy Prankster of Modernism|publisher=}}</ref>
==Works== *[[Alice Aycock]] - "Whirpools" at [[MGM National Harbor|MGM]] [[National Harbor]], [[Oxon Hill]], [[Maryland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multivu.com/players/English/77609242-mgm-national-harbor-heritage-collection/|title=MGM National Harbor to Feature Permanent Art Collection Inspired by Capital Region’s Rich Heritage|first=MultiVu - PR|last=Newswire|website=Multivu}}</ref> *[[Kevin Beasley]] - *Who's Afraid to Listen to Red, Black and Green?" [[Morningside Park (New York City)|Morningside Park]], New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.studiomuseum.org/exhibition/inharlem-kevin-beasley-morningside-par|title=The Studio Museum in Harlem|website=www.studiomuseum.org}}</ref> *[[Christo and Jeanne-Claude]] - [[The Floating Piers]] on [[Lake Iseo]] near [[Brescia, Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/inside-story-christo-floating-piers-180959072/|title=The Inside Story of Christo's Floating Piers|first=Jeff|last=MacGregor|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/leisure/arts-and-culture/a6826/christo-floating-piers/|title=What It's Like to Walk on Water at Christo's Floating Piers|date=1 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:Iseo Floating Piers 7.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Floating Piers by Christo and Jeanne-Claude on Lake Iseo near Brescia, Italy]] *[[Michael Dean (artist)|Michael Dean]] - ''United Kingdom poverty line for two adults and two children: twenty thousand four hundred and thirty six pounds sterling as published on 1st September 2016'' (installation).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/culture/arts/massive-buttocks-coin-theft-warning-turner-prize-2016-show/|title=Massive buttocks and coin theft warning at Turner Prize 2016 Tate show|date=26 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[Jeremy Deller]] - ''[[We’re Here Because We’re Here (art event)|We’re Here Because We’re Here]]'' (event staged across U.K. July 1).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/jul/01/wearehere-battle-somme-tribute-acted-out-across-britain|title=#Wearehere: Somme tribute revealed as Jeremy Deller work|last=Higgins|first=Charlotte|date=2016-07-01|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|accessdate=2017-01-22}}</ref> *[[Bob Dylan]] - "Portal" at MGM National Harbor Oxon Hill, Maryland.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/08/arts/music/bob-dylan-iron-archway-casino.html|title=Another Side of Bob Dylan: Iron Sculptor|publisher=}}</ref> *[[Carsten Holler]] - Slide addition to [[Anish Kapoor]]'s [[Arcelormittal Orbit]] at [[Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park]] in [[London, England]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?ie=UTF-8&client=ms-android-att-us&source=android-browser&q=holler+slide+opwning+kapooe|title=holler slide opwning kapooe - Google Search|website=www.google.com}}</ref> *[[Chul Hyun Ahn]] - "The Wells" at MGM National Harbor, Oxon Hill, Maryland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/retail-restaurants-public-art-spotlighted-sneak-peek-mgm-national-harbor|title=Las Vegas Review-Journal|website=Las Vegas Review-Journal}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wanderingeducators.com/best/traveling/artworks-wonderful-whimsical-heritage-collection-mgm-national-harbor.html|title=Artworks from the Wonderful to the Whimsical: The Heritage Collection at MGM National Harbor|date=9 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref> *[[Martin Jennings]] - **''[[:File:Mary Seacole statue, St Thomas' Hospital, front view.jpg|Mary Seacole]]'' (sculpture, [[St Thomas' Hospital]], London). **''Women of Steel'' (sculpture, [[Sheffield]], England). *Carolyn Palmer - ''[[Lucille Ball (sculpture)#Second statue|Lucille Ball]]'' (sculpture, second and permanent replacement version, [[Celoron, New York]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/entertainment/the-wrap/article/Lucille-Ball-Scary-Statue-Replaced-With-A-9126773.php|title=Lucille Ball Scary’ Statue Replaced With a Less Nightmare-Inducing One|date=6 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *''[[Pikachu (sculpture)|Pikachu]]'' (anonymous sculptor, New Orleans, Louisiana).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/unofficial-pikachu-pokemonument-statue-erected-in-new-orleans/|title=Unofficial Pikachu Pokemonument statue erected in New Orleans|date=3 August 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *[[Martin Puryear]] - ''Big Bling''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brooklynrail.org/2016/07/artseen/martin-puryear-big-bling|title=MARTIN PURYEAR Big Bling|website=The Brooklyn Rail}}</ref>
==Awards== *[[Hugo Boss Prize]] - [[Anicka Yi]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/21/arts/design/hugo-boss-prize-guggenheim-foundation-anicka-yi.html?_r=0|title=Artist of Olfactory Appeal Wins Hugo Boss Prize|publisher=}}</ref> *[[The Hepworth Prize for Sculpture]]: [[Helen Marten]]<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-38014384 | title = Hepworth Prize winner Helen Marten pledges to share £30,000 sculpture award |date = 18 November 2016| accessdate = 5 December 2016|publisher = BBC News}}</ref> *[[Turner Prize]]: [[Helen Marten]]<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-38212014 | title = Turner Prize: Helen Marten wins 2016 award |date = 5 December 2016| accessdate = 5 December 2016|publisher = BBC News}}</ref>
==Deaths== *[[January 2]] - [[Marcel Barbeau]], 90, Canadian painter and sculptor *[[January 6]] - [[Uche Okeke]], 83, Nigerian artist *[[January 10]] **[[David Bowie]], 69, British singer-songwriter, actor, visual artist and art collector **[[Bård Breivik]], 67, Norwegian sculptor <ref>[http://www.bt.no/kultur/Bard-Breivik-er-dod-3519052.html Bård Breivik er død] {{no icon}}</ref> **[[Cornelis Zitman]], 89, Dutch born Venezuelan sculptor. *[[January 13]] - [[Lois Weisberg]], 90, Cultural affairs commissioner of [[Chicago]] (1988-2011) *[[January 14]] - [[Sergio Vacchi]], 90, Italian painter *[[January 16]] - [[Joannis Avramidis]], 93, Georgian-born Austrian sculptor *[[January 17]] **[[Melvin Day]], 92, New Zealand artist **[[Gottfried Honegger]], 98, Swiss artist and graphic designer *[[January 25]] - [[Thornton Dial]], 87, American artist *[[February 11]] - [[Charles Garabedian]], 92, Armenian American painter *[[February 10]] - [[Douglas Haynes]], 80, Canadian painter *[[February 12]] – [[Sossen Krohg]], 92, Norwegian actor and theatre director<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.vg.no/rampelys/tv/tv-serier/sossen-krohg-er-doed/a/23615286 | title=Sossen Krohg er død | language=Norwegian | last=Dahl | first=Ingvill Dybfest | work=[[Verdens Gang]] | date=2016-02-12 | accessdate=2016-02-19}}</ref> *[[February 16]] ** [[Eugenio Carmi]], 95. '''Alexander Kircher''' (Trieste, 26 February 1867 – 16 September 1939, Berlin) was an Austrian-German marine and landscape painter and illustrator. Many of his paintings can be seen in museums in [[Germany]], [[Austria]], [[Croatia]], and [[Slovenia]] while others are held by private owners in those same countries, as well as the [[United States of America]], [[Great Britain]], [[Scandinavia]], and [[Greece]].
From time to time Kircher's paintings are presented for sale at such leading auction houses as [[Christie's]] and [[Bonhams]] in London, [[Sotheby's]] in New York, the Burchard Galleries in St. Petersburg, Florida,<ref>[http://www.burchardgalleries.com/ Burchard Galleries] Antiques and Arts Auctioneer, St. Petersburg/Florida</ref> Stahl Hamburg,<ref>[https://www.auktionshaus-stahl.de/ Auction house Stahl], Hamburg, Germany</ref> Van Ham Cologne,<ref>[http://www.van-ham.com/en/van-ham-new-building.html VAN HAM Fine Art Auctioneers], Cologne, Germany</ref> the [[Dorotheum]] in Vienna, and several others.
The artist signed the majority of his paintings "Alex Kircher", sometimes adding the year of their creation. The Bergmann Auction House in Erlangen, Germany, maintains a directory of Kircher's various signature styles.<ref>[http://www.auktion-bergmann.de/Katalog.aspx?text=Kircher&KatNo=0&a_id=3&cui=EN Signature Directory Auction House Bergmann, Erlangen, Germany]</ref>
==Life== [[File:Alexander Kircher and his wife aboard his Austrian steam yacht Romana c.1902.png|thumb|Kircher and his wife aboard his motor yacht ''Romana'', about 1910]] [[File:Alexander Kircher with his wife on his steamer yacht Romana, circa 1912.png|thumb|Coffee time aboard the ''Romana'', about 1910]] [[File:SMS Budapest, at a buoy maneuvers with Alexander Kircher on the bow - 1902.png|thumb|Kircher on the bow of {{SMS|Budapest}} during buoy manoeuvres in 1902 <ref>[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:SMS_Budapest,_at_a_buoy_maneuvers_with_Alexander_Kircher_on_the_bow_-_1902_-_Back_of_the_photo.png Back of the photograph with date and dedication of Alexander Kircher]</ref>]] [[File:Dresden nach 1904 - Haus Johannstädter Ufer 16 - Annahme.jpg|thumb|The house at 16 Johannstädter Ufer in Dresden, where Kircher and his family lived from 1904 to 1906 <ref>[http://www.sachsendigital.de/ressourcen/quellen/dresdner-adressbuecher/ SLUB Historical address books Dresden, 1702 - 1944]</ref>]] [[File:Rathaus Moritzburg.JPG|thumb|The house at 22 Schlossallee in Moritzburg, where Kircher and his family lived from 1907 to 1921]] [[File:Germany, Saxony - Villa in the Lößnitz, around 1930.png|thumb|The villa at 6 Jagdweg, Niederlößnitz, where Kircher and his family lived from 1922 to 1933]] Kircher was born in [[Trieste]], which belonged at that time to the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]] ([[Habsburg Monarchy]]). As a young man he intended to choose the profession of a naval officer in the [[Austro-Hungarian Navy]]. Because of a foot injury his application was rejected. In 1888 he opted for studying painting at the [[Prussian Academy of Arts|Berlin Academy]], where he concentrated mainly on marine painting from the start. His teachers were [[Hans Gude]] and [[Hermann Eschke]].
Kircher made numerous study trips throughout Europa, Asia, North America and Egypt. During these travels, he made several important paintings, drawings and illustrations. In 1893 he worked on the picturesque decoration of buildings at the [[World's Columbian Exposition|World Exhibition in Chicago]] as well as panoramas and dioramas of the marine painter [[:de:Hans von Petersen]]. In addition, Kircher worked as an illustrator for popular German and foreign magazines and publishers of which only a few can be mentioned: The Leipziger Illustrierte Zeitung or the modern illustrated weekly Reclams universe (Leipzig), the writings of the Austrian (Vienna) and the [[Navy League (Germany)|German fleet association]] (Berlin) and the Viennese publisher Philipp & Kramer, for which he designed the postcard series "Dalmatia and Istria".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://istriadalmaziacards.com/html/collezioni_pers_dett.php?IDCat=3&IDPers=83 |title=Historical Postcards of Istria, Rijeka, Kvarner and Dalmatia |access-date=2015-01-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110144454/http://istriadalmaziacards.com/html/collezioni_pers_dett.php?IDCat=3&IDPers=83 |archive-date=2015-01-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> These include Feldpost, postcards which Kircher created for the [[Austrian Red Cross]], the War Welfare Office or the War Aid Office and also for the London Postcard Publisher [[Raphael Tuck & Sons]] and the Swedish Postcards Publisher: "Gothenburg Lithographic AB and Meyer & Köster" etc. For some time Kircher owned a steam yacht, which he named ''Romana'' – this was his wife's name. With this ship he could better motives collect and draw maritime objects from the area. This he did for example in fleet parades.
[[File:SMS NOVARA - Weltumseglung 1857-1859 - Astronavigation auf See - 70 Cent.jpg|thumb|Austrian 70-cent stamps commemorating the SMS ''Novara'''s 1857–1859 round-the-world voyage using celestial navigation, featuring a painting by A. Kircher]] [[File:Familiengrab der Kirchers auf dem Friedhof von Moritzburg.png|thumb|The Kircher family grave in the cemetery at Moritzburg in Saxony]] Between 1895 and 1900 he was a professor at the Art Academy in Trieste and married Romana Salmassi<ref>[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Document_of_the_Gross-parents_Kircher-Salmassi.jpg Excerpt from the ancestry certificate of Alexander Kircher and Romana Salmassi]</ref> in the Chiesa di Sant'Antonio Taumaturgo<ref>[[:de:Sant’Antonio Taumaturgo|The Church of Sant'Antonio Traumaturgo in Trieste]]</ref> on 15 October 1898. This marriage produced three sons and three daughters. In 1904, after a short stay in Vienna, Kircher moved from Trieste to [[Dresden]], where he lived until 1906 and where he joined the General German Art Cooperative as a freelance artist. In 1906 the family moved to [[Moritzburg, Saxony|Moritzburg]]. From 1922 the Kirchers occupied a villa at 6 Jagdweg in [[Niederlößnitz]] and from 1933 to about 1935 they lived in [[Kötzschenbroda]]-Niederlößnitz.<ref>[[Radebeul]] - Niederlößnitz is today a part of the city of Radebeul/Meißen in Saxony</ref> In June 1935, Kircher's wife died. The painter then moved to [[Klotzsche]], where he took up residence in a building belonging to the former [[Air War School Klotzsche|Air War School]] in that town.
Influential members of the nobility and some industrialists – especially from the circles of Maritime Navigation<ref>[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Anniversary_edition_70_years_North_German_Lloyd_with_the_dedication_of_Alexander_Kircher.jpg Anniversary edition 70 years [[North German Lloyd]] with the dedication to Alexander Kircher]</ref> – promoted the artist. First of them [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Emperor Franz Joseph I]] and [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Emperor Wilhelm II]]. On behalf of these two monarchs, Kircher painted numerous images of the [[Austro-Hungarian Navy]] and the [[Imperial German Navy]]. His paintings were also found on the large passenger ships of the time, as well as in the offices of well known shipping companies and shipyards and of course also in private ownership. During World War II, several images got lost or disappeared. An example of the many lost images is the large oil painting of the steamship [[SS Columbus (1924)|''Columbus'']] ("The Columbus in the Kaiser lock"). This painting was given by the [[North German Lloyd]] as a gift to the city of [[Bremerhaven]] on the occasion of its 100th anniversary in 1927. The painting has disappeared at the end of World War II (1945). Others of his paintings have been preserved for posterity and can be seen in many museums today; see list of locations excerpt.
Kircher concluded his life's work with a series of one hundred paintings which documented the development of German shipping over a millennium and which hung in the Institute and Museum of Oceanography MfM. of the University of Berlin. The current location of the works is unknown, reproductions have since appeared as an image panel work (1934) and in book form (1939)<ref>[http://www.abebooks.com/Deutschlands-Seegeltung-Germansichen-Einbaum-Wikingerschiff-deutschen/12378574956/bd Wolfgang Loeff: Deutschlands Seegeltung, Berlin, 1939] in German language</ref> and recently only in parts on CD-ROM (2010).<ref>[http://www.historischer-bilderdienst.de/marinebilder/alexander-kircher-marinemaler/index.php Alexander Kircher, marine painter - Historical Image Service]</ref> Meanwhile, 22 images, of which the majority is from the collection of MfM, were rediscovered in the archives of Wehrgeschichtliches Training Centre of the [[Naval Academy Mürwik]] in [[Flensburg]]-[[Mürwik]]. Kircher died on 16 September 1939, in Berlin, the last place where he had worked. The painter was laid to rest in the family grave in Moritzburg, Saxony.
==Awards and decorations== Kircher received the Spanish [[Order of Isabella the Catholic]] in February 1909 in the Spanish Embassy in Berlin. This award will be given for services to art and science.

===Larger Image collections=== * In addition to the selection of the above pictures large stocks of Kircher paintings exist in the Military History Museum (HGM) in Vienna and the Archduke Franz Ferdinand Museum in Artstetten in Lower Austria. Moreover, in Germany in the Naval Academy, Flensburg-Mürwik and there some Kircher paintings are shown in the commander Villa. In Croatia in the museum of the city of Rovinj and Split in the Maritime Museum. Of course, there are also numerous paintings in private ownership.
===Stolen artwork=== * The original painting: ''"LZ 127 Graf Zeppelin with Russian icebreaker Malygin"'' from 1931, dimensions: 26.00 x 39.00 inch, formerly part of the Reichspostmuseum in Berlin - 1945 after the end of the Second World War this image was lost.<ref>[http://www.lostart.de/Webs/DE/Datenbank/EinzelobjektVerlust.html?cms_param=EOBJ_ID%3D459617 German Center for Cultural Property Loss, Lost Art-ID: 459617]</ref> - The painting was auctioned at Cowan's Auctions <ref>[https://www.cowanauctions.com/ Cowan's Auctions, Cincinnati OH]</ref> in Cincinnati, Ohio, USA for US $19,550 in 2005. Since then, the painting has been at Pullman Gallery in London,<ref>[http://www.pullmangallery.com/ Pullman Gallery, London]</ref> a return to the Museum of Communication in Frankfurt am Main (Legal successor to the Reichspostmuseum) has not yet taken place.<ref>[http://lootedart.tumblr.com Looted art]</ref><ref>[http://www.findartinfo.com/german/list-prices-by-artist/1/2529/alexander-kircher/page/2.html Alexander Kircher by FINDARTINFO COM] ~ date: 02-03-2005 ~ name: ''Fantastic Arctic Scene With The Graf Zeppelin'' ~ size: 26,00 x 39,00 inch ~ Oil on canvas ~ price: 19.550 USD.</ref>

Gaz 'Geordie' Stoker }} '''Angelic Upstarts''' are an English [[punk rock]] band formed in [[South Shields]] in 1977. [[Allmusic]] calls them "one of the period's most politically charged and thought-provoking groups".[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p12222|pure_url=yes}} Angelic Upstarts Biography]. [[Allmusic]]. URL accessed 3 July 2006. The band espoused an [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]] and [[Socialism|socialist]] [[working class]] philosophy, and have been associated with the [[skinhead]] [[subculture]]Though they ended up detesting and being detested by most skinheads. The band released eight studio albums in their first decade.http://www.discogs.com/artist/148396-Angelic-Upstarts After a brief split they reformed in 1988, and a number of times subsequently, with new albums appearing in 1992, 2002, 2011, and 2016. More than two decades after its release, their debut single, "The Murder Of [[Liddle Towers]]", was included in ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' magazine’s list of the best punk rock singles of all time.Mojo (October 2001) - ''100 Punk Scorchers '', Issue 95, London; ==Lineups== {{refimprove section|date=December 2013}} The band's original members were Thomas Mensforth (Mensi) on vocals, Ray Cowie (Mond) on [[guitar]], Steve Forsten on [[bass guitar]], and Derek "Decca" Wade on [[Drum kit|drums]]. Keith Bell was the manager until 1980, when he was jailed for four and a half years for arson.{{cite web|last=Bradbury |first=Jennifer |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/tm_objectid=16853928&method=full&siteid=50081&headline=still-crazy-after-all-these-years-name_page.html |title=Still crazy after all these years |publisher=ChronicleLive |date=2006-03-23 |accessdate=2012-04-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430152415/http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/tm_objectid%3D16853928%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D50081%26headline%3Dstill-crazy-after-all-these-years-name_page.html |archivedate=30 April 2012 }} Other former members include Ronnie Rocker and bassists Ronnie Wooden, Glyn Warren and Tony Feedback (now in [[Long Tall Shorty]] and [[Kiria (musician)|Kiria]]'s live band). Drummers have included Sticks Warrington (who later joined [[Cockney Rejects]]), [[Paul Thompson (musician)|Paul Thompson]] (ex-[[Roxy Music]]), Chris White, Evo (who has also played in [[The Blood]], [[Major Accident]] and Warfare. Wade rejoined the band for a few years before leaving again. Brian Hayes (also of Blaggers ITA, Long Tall Shorty) originally joined the band as second guitarist until Mond left, leaving Hayes as the only guitarist. Mensi was the only original member still in the band. In August 2006, Mensi announced he was resigning, but requested that the band continue with Chris Wright (of the band Crashed Out) on vocals. The band's lineup became Wright on vocals, Dickie Hammond on guitar, Neil "Newts" Newton on guitar, Gaz "Geordie" Stoker on bass and Wade on drums. In the latter part of 2007, Mensi rejoined the band and the lineup became Mensi on vocals, Gaz "Geordie" Stoker on bass, Hammond on guitar, Newts on guitar and Brett Mulvaney (and later Jonnie Halling) on drums. The current lineup is now Mensi on vocals, Newts Newton on guitar, GG Gates on bass and Sgt Wilko on drums.http://officialangelicupstarts.com/about ==Influence== Angelic Upstarts are regarded as pioneers of the [[Oi!]] punk [[music genre|subgenre]].http://www.allmusic.com/album/punk-singles-collection-mw0000474679 In 2001, Various Artists [[cover album]] ''We Are the People'' was released in tribute to the Upstarts, including tracks from bands such as [[Leatherface (band)|Leatherface]], [[The Oppressed]], [[Red London]] and [[Red Alert (band)|Red Alert]].http://www.allmusic.com/album/were-the-people-tribute-to-angelic-upstarts-mw0000971221 In 2009, punk-influenced singer-songwriter [[Jamie T]] sampled vocals from the album ''Angelic Upstarts Live'' on his song "[[The Man's Machine]]". ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== *''[[Teenage Warning]]'' (August 1979, [[Warner Bros. {{Short description|1927 painting by Edward Hopper}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=HopperAutomat.jpg | title=Automat | artist=[[Edward Hopper]] | year=1927 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=71.4 | width_metric=91.4 | height_imperial=28 | width_imperial=36 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Des Moines | museum=Des Moines Art Center }}
'''''Automat''''' is a [[1927 in art|1927]] painting by the [[Visual arts of the United States|American]] [[Realism (arts)|realist]] [[painting|painter]] [[Edward Hopper]]. The painting was first displayed on Valentine’s Day 1927 at the opening of Hopper’s second solo show, at the Rehn Galleries in [[New York City]]. By April it had been sold for $1,200.<ref>Carol Troyen, ''Hopper in Gloucester,'' in Carol Troyen, Judith Barter, Janet Comey, [[Elliot Bostwick Davis]] and Ellen Roberts (eds.), ''Edward Hopper''. Boston: MFA Publications (Museum of Fine Arts), 2007, p. 72.</ref> The painting is today owned by the [[Des Moines Art Center]] in Iowa.
==The woman== The painting portrays a lone woman staring into a cup of coffee in an [[automat]] at night. The reflection of identical rows of light fixtures stretches out through the night-blackened window.
Hopper's wife, [[Josephine Hopper|Jo]], served as the model for the woman.<ref>Gail Levin, ''Edward Hopper: An Intimate Biography.'' New York: Rizzoli, (1995) 2007, p. 201.</ref> However, Hopper altered her face to make her younger (Jo was 44 in 1927). He also altered her figure; Jo was a curvy, full-figured woman, while one critic has described the woman in the painting as {{"'}}boyish' (that is, flat-chested)".<ref name="ReferenceB">Carol Troyen, ''{{'}}The Sacredness of Everyday Fact': Hopper’s Pictures of the City''. In Carol Troyen, Judith Barter, Janet Comey, [[Elliot Bostwick Davis]] and Ellen Roberts (eds.), ''Edward Hopper''. Boston: MFA Publications (Museum of Fine Arts), 2007, p. 118.</ref>
As is often the case in Hopper's paintings, both the woman's circumstances and her mood are ambiguous. She is well-dressed and is wearing makeup, which could indicate either that she is on her way to or from work at a job where personal appearance is important, or that she is on her way to or from a social occasion.
She has removed only one glove, which may indicate either that she is distracted, that she is in a hurry and can stop only for a moment, or simply that she has just come in from outside, and has not yet warmed up. But the latter possibility seems unlikely, for there is a small empty plate on the table, in front of her cup and saucer, suggesting that she may have eaten a snack and been sitting at this spot for some time.
The time of year—late autumn or winter—is evident from the fact that the woman is warmly dressed. But the time of day is unclear, since days are short at this time of year. It is possible, for example, that it is just after sunset, and early enough in the evening that the automat could be the spot at which she has arranged to rendezvous with a friend. Or it could be late at night, after the woman has completed a shift at work. Or again, it could be early in the morning, before sunrise, as a shift is about to start.
Whatever the hour, the restaurant appears to be largely empty and there are no signs of activity (or of any life at all) on the street outside. This adds to the sense of loneliness, and has caused the painting to be popularly associated with the concept of [[Urban sociology|urban alienation]]. One critic has observed that, in a pose typical of Hopper's melancholic subjects, "the woman's eyes are downcast and her thoughts turned inward."<ref>Iversen, Margaret, ''Edward Hopper''. [[Tate Publishing Ltd|Tate Publishing]], 2004, p. 57.</ref> Another critic has described her as "gazing at her coffee cup as if it were the last thing in the world she could hold on to."<ref>Schmied, Wieland, ''Edward Hopper: Portraits of America''. Translated by John William Gabriel. Munich: Prestel, 1999, p. 76.</ref> In 1995, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine used ''Automat'' as the cover image for a story about stress and depression in the 20th century.<ref>''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, August 28, 1995.</ref>
Art critic Ivo Kranzfelder compares the subject matter of this painting (a young woman nursing a drink alone in a restaurant) to [[Édouard Manet]]'s ''[[The Plum]]'' and [[Edgar Degas]]'s ''[[L'Absinthe]]''<ref>Ivo Kranzfelder, ''Hopper''. Cologne, Germany: Benedikt Taschen, 2010, p. 146.</ref>—although unlike the subject in Degas's painting, the woman is introspective, rather than dissipated.
==The viewer’s perspective== The presence of a chairback in the lower right-hand corner of the canvas suggests that the viewer is sitting at a nearby table, from which vantage-point a stranger might be able to glance, uninvited, upon the woman.
In an innovative twist, Hopper made the woman’s legs the brightest spot in the painting, thereby "turning her into an object of desire" and "making the viewer a voyeur."<ref>Robert Hobbs, ''Edward Hopper''. New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1987, p. 72.</ref> By today’s standards this description seems overstated, but in 1927 the public display of women’s legs was still a relatively novel phenomenon.
Hopper would make the crossed legs of a female subject the brightest spot on an otherwise dark canvas in a number of later paintings, including ''[[Compartment C, Car 293]]'' (1938)[http://artsandletters.files.wordpress.com/2009/01/hopper-compartment-c-car-293-image-geoffrey-clements-corbis.jpg] and ''[[Hotel Lobby]]'' (1943).[http://ayiajavon.com/imd100/g2.jpg]<ref>The comparison between ''Automat'' and ''Hotel Lobby'' is made in Robert Hobbs, ''Edward Hopper.'' New York: Harry N. Abrams, 1987, p. 137.</ref> The female subject of his 1931 painting ''[[Barber Shop]]''[http://www.artsfairies.com/Edward_Hopper/Hopper_Edward_The_Barber_Shop.jpg] is also in a pose similar to the woman in ''Automat'', and the viewer's image of her is similarly bisected by a table. But the placing of the subject in a bright, populated place, at midday, makes the woman less isolated and vulnerable, and hence the viewer's gaze seems less intrusive.
==The restaurant== As critic Carol Troyen notes, "the title, rather than any detail within the picture, is what identifies the restaurant as an automat."<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Troyen continues on, however, to note a number of features which would have made the restaurant identifiable to a New Yorker of the 1920s: "They were clean, efficient, well-lit and—typically furnished with round Carrera marble tables and solid oak chairs like those shown here—genteel. By the time Hopper painted his picture, automats had begun to be promoted as safe and proper places for the working woman to dine alone."<ref name="ReferenceB"/> To a New Yorker of the 1920s, Hopper's interior would have been instantly recognizable as an Automat. A 1912 photograph of the Automat in [[Times Square]] reveals every detail of the chairs and the marble-topped tables to correspond with what Hopper has painted.<ref>See photograph in Lorraine B. Diehl and Marianne Hardart, ''The Automat: The History, Recipes, and Allure of Horn and Hardart's Masterpiece.'' New York: Clarkson Potter, 2002, p. 26.</ref> However, this is not the Times Square Automat; the ceiling lights at that location were significantly more ornate than the ones in the painting.
Automats, which were open at all hours of the day, were also “busy, noisy and anonymous. They served more than ten thousand customers a day."<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Moreover, the woman is sitting in the least congenial spot in the entire restaurant for introspection. She has, as Troyen notes, the table nearest the door, and behind her, on her other side, is the staircase to the restaurant’s below-ground level. Even if the restaurant were relatively empty, there would have been constant foot-traffic past her table. Thus, "the figure’s quiet, contemplative air," which is "out of step with the city’s energy, its pace and its mechanized rhythm,"<ref name="ReferenceB"/> is made even more noteworthy by the particularly busy spot in which she has chosen to sit.
==The window== Hopper’s paintings are frequently built around a [[Vignette (literature)|vignette]] that unfolds as the viewer gazes into a window, or out through a window. Sometimes, as in ''[[Railroad Sunset]]'' (1929),[http://www.sai.msu.su/cjackson/hopper/hopper12.jpg] ''[[Nighthawks]]'' (1942) and ''[[Office in a Small City]]'' (1953), it is still possible to see details of the scene beyond even after Hopper has guided the viewer’s gaze through two panes of glass. When Hopper wishes to obscure the view, he tends to position the window at a sharp angle to the viewer’s vantage-point, or to block the view with curtains or blinds. Another favourite technique—used, for example, in ''[[Conference at Night]]'' (1949),[http://www.artsfairies.com/Edward_Hopper/Hopper_Edward_Conference_At_Night.jpg]—is to use bright light, flooding in from the exterior at a sharp angle from the sun or from an unseen streetlight, to illuminate a few mundane details within inches of the far side of the window, thereby throwing the deeper reaches of the view into shadow.
By way of comparison, in ''Automat'' the window dominates the painting, and yet "allows nothing of the street, or whatever else is outside, to be seen."<ref name="ReferenceA">Mark Strand, ''Hopper''. New York: Knopf, 2007, p. 43.</ref> The complete blackness outside is a departure both from Hopper’s usual techniques, and from realism, since a New York street at night is full of light from cars and street lamps. This complete emptiness allows the reflections from the interior to stand out more dramatically, and intensifies the viewer’s focus upon the woman.
The window conveys an impressionistic view, rather than one that is realistic, in another way. As [[Mark Strand]] notes, "The window reflects only the twin receding rows of ceiling lights and nothing else of the automat interior." It is possible that Hopper omitted these reflections in order to avoid distractions that might turn the viewer’s away from the woman. Strand, however, suggests an alternative reason why the woman’s reflection is omitted:
{{cquote|The painting suggests several things, but the most obvious and most resonant is that if what the window reflects is true then the scene takes place in limbo and the seated woman is an illusion. This is a troubling idea. And if the woman thinks of herself in this context, she cannot possibly be happy. But of course she does not think, she is the product of another will, an illusion, an invention of Hopper’s.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>}} The focusing effect of the blank window behind the woman can be seen most clearly when it is contrasted with ''[[Sunlight in a Cafeteria]]'' (1958),[http://www.museumsyndicate.com/images/1/9792.jpg]<ref>The comparison between ''Automat'' and ''Sunlight in a Cafeteria'' is made in Ivo Kranzfelder, ''Hopper''. Cologne, Germany: Benedikt Taschen, 2010, p. 146, and in Lloyd Goodrich, ''Edward Hopper''. New York: Abradale Press / Harry N. Abrams, 1983, p. 133.</ref> one of Hopper’s late paintings. In that painting, a female and a male subject sit in an otherwise empty cafeteria in spots reminiscent of the tables occupied, respectively, by the female subject and the viewer in ''Automat''. Even the bowl of fruit on the windowsill in ''Automat'' has its parallel in a small potted plant on the windowsill in ''Sunlight in a Cafeteria''. But in ''Sunlight in a Cafeteria'', the well-illuminated street scene outside the large window seemingly distracts the man's attention from his counterpart, so that the two subjects "do not seem to be acting in the same scene, as it were."<ref>Rolf Gunter Renner, ''Edward Hopper''. Cologne, Germany: Benedikt Taschen, 1990, p. 81.</ref> By contrast, in ''Automat'' the viewer is fully engaged by the presence of the woman.

{{Infobox website | name = Avalon Project | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = <!-- or: | logocaption = --> | screenshot = | collapsible = <!-- set as "on", "y", etc, otherwise omit/leave blank --> | collapsetext = <!-- collapsible area's heading (default "Screenshot"); omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = | screenshot_alt = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://avalon.law.yale.edu/}} | areas = | offices = | commercial = No | type = Digital library | registration = | language = English | num_users = | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | programming_language = | owner = [[Lillian Goldman Law Library]] | author = <!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = <!-- or: | editors = --> | launch_date = <!-- {{Start date and age|df=yes/no|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | revenue = | alexa = <!-- {{IncreaseNegative}} {{Steady}} {{DecreasePositive}} [https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/example.com example.com Traffic Statistics] --> | ip = | issn = <!-- ISSN, e.g. 1085-6706 (automatically linked to https://www.WorldCat.org) --> | eissn = <!-- eISSN, e.g. 1085-6706 (automatically linked to https://www.WorldCat.org) --> | oclc = <!-- OCLC number, useful where an ISSN has not been allocated (automatically linked to https://www.WorldCat.org) --> | current_status = | footnotes = }} {{Other uses|Avalon (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=September 2018}} The '''Avalon Project''' is a [[digital library]] of documents relating to [[law]], [[history]] and [[diplomacy]]. The project is part of the [[Yale Law School]] [[Lillian Goldman Law Library]].
The project contains online electronic copies of documents dating back to the beginning of history, making it possible to study the original text of not only very famous documents such as the [[Magna Carta]], the [[English Bill of Rights]], and the [[United States Bill of Rights]], but also the text of less well known but significant documents which mark turning points in the history of law and rights.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://chnm.gmu.edu/worldhistorysources/r/211/whm.html |title=Avalon Project: Documents in Law, History and Diplomacy |website=Center for History and New Media |publisher=[[George Mason University]]}}</ref>
{{Quote|source=Statement of Purpose<ref>{{cite web|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/about/purpose.asp|title=Avalon Project - Statement of Purpose|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref>|text=The Avalon Project will mount digital documents relevant to the fields of Law, History, Economics, Politics, Diplomacy and Government. We do not intend to mount only static text but rather to add value to the text by linking to supporting documents expressly referred to in the body of the text.}}
The site has full search facilities and a facility to electronically compare the text of two documents. It also hosts ''Project Diana: An Online [[Human Rights]] Archive''.

{{Infobox company | name = C3 Presents | logo = C3presents_logo.png | logo_size = 100px | caption = | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|2007}} | founder = Charles Attal, Charlie Jones and Charlie Walker | defunct = | location_city = [[Austin, Texas]] | location_country = [[United States]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Concert promotion, event production and artist management | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|C3Presents.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''C3 Presents''' is a concert promotion, event production and artist management company based out of [[Austin, Texas]].[https://www.c3presents.com/ C3 Presents] C3 also produces several iconic multi-day festivals including Austin City Limits Music Festival in Texas,[https://www.aclfestival.com/ ACL Music Festival] Voodoo Music + Arts Experience in New Orleans,[https://www.voodoofestival.com/ Voodoo Festival] and Lollapalooza in Chicago along with its six international editions.[https://www.lollapalooza.com/ Lollapalooza] ==History== C3[https://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2010-10-08/big-dogs-young-rebels-and-aging-giants/ Austin Chronicle Blog] was founded by Charles Attal, Charlie Jones and Charlie Walker in 2007(2)[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/07/arts/music/07lolla.html NY Times] and headquartered in Austin, TX, with offices in Los Angeles, Atlanta, and New Orleans. The company also promotes more than 1,100 concerts annual in arenas, casinos and clubs throughout North America. In the Fall of 2014, Live Nation began talks to purchase a 51% stake in the Austin company’s events production and promotions businesses.[https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6414053/live-nation-completes-deal-for-c3-presents Live Nation Completes Deal][https://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/music/2015-02-26/c3-presents-and-live-nation-team-up/ C3 and LiveNation Team Up][https://consequenceofsound.net/2014/12/live-nation-acquires-controlling-interest-in-lollapaloozaacl-promoter-c3-presents/ Consequence Of Sound] At the time, C3 was largest independent concert promoter in the world.[https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/blog/at-the-watercooler/2014/12/live-nation-buys-ownership-stake-in-austins Live Nation buys ownership stake] The deal was completed in December of that year. ==Events== Annually, C3 Presents produces the following festivals: • All Things Go Fall Classic[https://www.allthingsgofallclassic.com All Things Go]

• Obama Election Night Celebration (2008 and 2012) [https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/1276167/c3-presents-to-provide-services-for-obama-concert-parade C3 Presents To Provide Services]{{cite web|author1=Ray Waddell|title=C3 Presents To Provide Services For Obama Concert, Parade|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/1276167/c3-presents-to-provide-services-for-obama-concert-parade|website=Billboard Biz|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=16 January 2009}}{{cite web|author1=Jack Goodall|title=BaROCK Obama’s Inauguration|url=http://www.thembj.org/2009/03/barock-obama’s-inauguration/|website=The Music Business Journal|publisher=[[Berklee College of Music]]|accessdate=25 January 2015|date=March 2009}}
• Obama White House Easter Egg Roll [https://www.pollstarpro.com/NewsContent.aspx?cat=&com=1&ArticleID=812013 PollstarPro] C3 also books and promotes over 1,000 shows nationwide, including Austin venues [[Stubb's BBQ]], [[Emo's]] and La Zona Rosa. ===Artist management=== In addition to promotion and production, C3 Presents also has an artist management division operating in New York City, Los Angeles, Nashville, and Austin. C3 Management has a current roster of over 50 musicians {{Cite web |url=http://www.c3presents.com/artistmanagement.aspx# |title=C3 Presents Clients |access-date=2010-12-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121064721/http://www.c3presents.com/artistmanagement.aspx# |archive-date=2010-11-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} including The Strokes, Phoenix, Lindsey Buckingham, My Bloody Valentine, The Head And The Heart, The Revivalists, Justice, Sylvan Esso, and Gramatik.[https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/legal-and-management/5869579/matt-shay-joins-c3s-management-division Matt Shay Joins] The company also maintains its own freestanding radio promotion, film/TV, digital, and creative staffs.[https://www.pollstarpro.com/NewsContent.aspx?cat=&com=1&ArticleID=812013 PollstarPro] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]]

page.title: Darfield Foulstone School of Creative Arts

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox UK school | name = Darfield Foulstone School Of Creative Arts | image = | size = | coordinates = {{coord|53.5348|-1.3749|type:edu_region:GB_dim:100|format=dec|display=inline,title}} | motto = Positive Foulstone, Moving Forward, Learning Together | motto_pl = | established = 1933 | approx = | closed = 2012 | c_approx = | type = Secondary School | religion = | president = | head_label = | head = | r_head_label = | r_head = | chair_label = | chair = | founder = | founder_pl = | specialist = Creative Arts | street = Nanny Marr Road | city = [[Darfield, South Yorkshire|Darfield]]
[[Barnsley]] | county = [[South Yorkshire]] | country = [[England]] | postcode = [[S73 9AB]] | LEA = [[Metropolitan Borough of Barnsley|Barnsley]] | ofsted = | staff = | enrollment = | lower_age = | upper_age = | gender = Mixed | houses = | colours = | publication = | free_label_1 = | free_1 = | free_label_2 = | free_2 = | free_label_3 = | free_3 = | website = http://www.foulstoneschool.co.uk/ | website_name = Darfield Foulstone School of Creative Arts }} '''Darfield Foulstone School of Creative Arts''' was a comprehensive school located in the village of [[Darfield, South Yorkshire|Darfield]], [[Barnsley]], [[South Yorkshire]]. It was a specialist creative arts school, with approximately 900 pupils between the ages of 11 and 16 before closure. ==History== The Foulstone Modern School was built on land in the centre of Darfield, previously occupied by a children's recreation ground and by well-cultivated allotments, running alongside of Nanny Marr Road. It was built in the late 1930s and officially opened by R. A. (Rab) Butler in the early war years. The aim of the school was to provide a good standard of secondary education for local children aged 11 to 16. A lot has been written about the standard and quality of secondary education in the 1930s; much appeared to revolve around the "11 plus exam", an examination taken by children aged 10/11 years old. The school derived its name from Alderman T.H. (Tommy) Foulstone who was Darfield's representative on the West Riding County Council (headquarters at Wakefield); his special interest was education, standards for which he sought to increase at all levels. The school formally closed in 2012, when it merged with Wombwell High School to form [[Netherwood Advanced Learning Centre]] on a new site.{{cite news|title=Work on New Dearne Link Bridge Is Finished |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-309605362.html |work=Epworth Bells |date=29 March 2012 |via=[[Highbeam]] |accessdate=26 April 2015}} ==Specialism== As part of its creative arts specialism, the school was the host of the [http://www.barnsleyyouththeatre.org.uk/index.html Barnsley Youth Theatre]. There was also a dance school, "K.A.D.S", run by one of the school's dance teachers. Adjoining the school was a [http://www.barnsleyclcs.org/ CLC] which had a subsequent auditorium, a professional recording studio, a cyber cafe, a MAC lab, and computer suites. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://foulstoneschool.co.uk Darfield Foulstone School of Creative Arts] * [http://www.barnsleyyouththeatre.org.uk/index.html Barnsley Youth Theatre] {{Schools in Barnsley}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Darfield Foulstone School Of Creative Arts}} [[Category:Defunct schools in Barnsley]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1933]] [[Category:1933 establishments in England]] [[Category:Educational institutions disestablished in 2012]] [[Category:2012 disestablishments in England]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1933]]

{{italic title}} <!-- Commented out: [[Image:Elmarbrandt.jpg|thumb|200px|Elmar Brandt with Gerhard Schröder puppet]] --> '''''Die Gerd-Show''''' ([[English language|en]]: '''''The Gerd Show''''') was a [[Germany|German]] [[satire|satirical]] radio show broadcast by [[Eins Live]] ([[Westdeutscher Rundfunk|WDR]]). Reaching over nine million listeners at its peak,<ref>{{cite news|title=Tax Song hits out|first=Eric|last=Culp|publisher=[[The Business (magazine)|The Business]]|date=17 November 2002}}</ref> it generated several Top 20 hits in the music charts in Germany, thanks to the [[impressionist (entertainment)|impressionist]] talents of its creator, [[Elmar Brandt]], as well as enough controversy over the show's good taste for it to receive newspaper coverage around the globe, despite the limited international appeal of German political humour.
==History==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Steuersong.jpg|thumb|200px|Cover of the ''Der Steuersong'' single]] --> The programme began in 1999, and was broadcast as a short daily comedy on various radio programmes. The most famous segments of these programmes were Elmar Brandt's rewrites of well-known tunes with new, satirical lyrics, which he sang in an imitation of the voice of [[Gerhard Schröder]], who at that time was [[Chancellor of Germany (Federal Republic)|Chancellor of Germany]]. These parodies generated six hits in the Top 20 in Germany, and were also popular in Switzerland and Austria.
The most successful of these was ''Der Steuersong'' (en: ''The Tax Song''), which reached the number one spot in Germany and Austria in 2002, and went double platinum in 2004, having sold over a million copies.<ref>{{cite news|title=Doppel-Platin für die «Gerd-Show» - «Steuer-Song» über eine Million Mal verkauft|publisher=ddp Landesdienste|date=8 March 2004}}</ref> Based on [[Las Ketchup]]'s summer dance hit ''[[Aserejé]]'', the song lampooned Schröder's tax policy, listing a number of perceived absurd [[indirect tax]]es (such as an tax on [[dog]]s) and suggesting new ones on breathing and bad weather, and depicting the Chancellor as a cheat and a promise breaker. The song was accompanied by a video, in which an unflattering ''[[Spitting Image]]'' style puppet of Schröder stole coins from a charity collection tin, and medicine from the sick.<ref name="Mocking">{{cite news|title=Song mocking Schröder tops German pop charts|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=20 November 2002}}</ref>
The song generated political controversy. Reports suggested that Schröder might take legal action, as he notoriously did—successfully—to stop a news agency printing claims that he dyed his hair,<ref>{{cite news|title=Schröder's good hair day in court|first=Toby|last=Helm|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=18 May 2002}}</ref> with a spokesman for Schröder's Social Democrats saying ''"There are limits even to political satire... We will take a look at the video, and the chancellor will have to examine what steps to take."''<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news|title=Hit Song Taxes German's Patience; Parody Mocks Schroeder on Economy|first=Peter|last=Finn|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|date=17 November 2002}}</ref>
Schröder did not in the end take legal action, but did call Brandt a ''"parasite"'' and ''"freeloader"'' for building a career on someone else's voice, to which Brandt rebutted ''"Freeloaders usually attach themselves to people who are successful"''.<ref name="Spars">{{cite news|title=Schröder spars with comedian over spoof song|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=5 December 2002}}</ref> The German tabloid ''[[Bild]]'' voiced indignation, asking ''"Can the chancellor be mocked like this?"'', though most thought that the song reflected genuine discontent with Schröder's tax policies and that Schröder took the song too seriously.<ref name="Mocking"/>
In 2003, Brandt took part in the German auditions for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2003]] with the song ''Alles wird gut'' (en: ''Everything's Going To Be Alright''). The act, which featured another puppet of Schröder simulating sex with the four backing singers, the "Gerdnerinnen" (Gerdettes, a word play on the German word for gardener), received 30% of the German vote, taking third place and losing out to [[Lou (singer)|Lou]]'s feel good anthem ''[[Let's Get Happy]]'' with 38%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Schröder's blushes are spared as comic fails at Eurovision|first=Ruth|last=Elkins|publisher=[[The Independent on Sunday]]|date=9 March 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Die Vorzeichen sind wieder dieselben|first=Bibiana|last=Holzhey|publisher=General-Anzeiger|date=10 March 2003}}</ref>
From 2005, [[Anne Onken]] imitated [[Angela Merkel]] on ''The Gerd Show'', who would later beat Schröder to become chancellor. During the run-up to the [[German federal election, 2005|2005 German federal elections]], a duet was released between Brandt as Schröder and Onken as Merkel, entitled ''Im Wahlkampf vor mir (Zonenmädchen)'' (en: ''Ahead of Me in the Polls (Girl from the East'')) and set to the tune of ''Im Wagen vor mir fährt ein junges Mädchen'' by [[Hans Blum (musician)|Hans Blum]]. Despite speculation that it would reach the top spot as ''Der Steuersong'' did before it,<ref>{{cite news|title=Schröder ballad challenges Crazy Frog for No 1 spot|first=Roger|last=Boyes|publisher=[[The Times]]|date=8 June 2005}}</ref> it only reached 25th place in the German charts.
In October 2005, ''The Gerd Show'' was cancelled with 1,300 episodes. Its place was taken by the radio serial ''Schicksalsjahre einer Kanzlerin – Angela – eine Frau geht seinen Weg'' (en: ''A Female Chancellor's Years of Destiny – Angela – A Woman Follows His <!-- ***NOTE***: 'Her' in German is 'ihren', 'his' is correct --> Path'', alluding to the [[Sissi_–_Fateful_Years_of_an_Empress|Sissi film trilogy]]), with Angela Merkel played by Anne Onken, and her male colleagues played by Elmar Brandt.
==Awards== *2003 – [[Echo (music award)|ECHO]] nomination, for ''Best National Rock Pop Single'' *2002 – [[Einslive Krone]], ''Best Comedy'' *1999 – [[Axel-Springer-Preis]] to [[Elmar Brandt]], for his imitation of Gerhard Schröder *1999 – [[Deutscher Comedypreis]], for ''Best Radio Comedy''
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== *''This article is partially based on a translation of the [[:de:Gerd-Show|corresponding German-language Wikipedia article]], retrieved on June 6, 2006.'' *[http://musicbrainz.org/artist/4958e33b-7b75-47f4-b913-1c67f024fb03.html ''Die Gerd Show''] at MusicBrainz
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gerd-Show}} [[Category:Political satire]] [[Category:Comedy radio programs]] [[Category:German radio programs]] [[Category:1999 radio programme debuts]]

revision.text:
{{for|the Scottish [[electoral reform]] campaign|Fairshare}} {{Primary sources|date=December 2007}}
'''FairShare''' is an idea for a voluntary [[investment]]-based [[patronage]] system to replace [[patents]] and [[copyright]] while still ensuring that artists are fairly compensated. It was designed by [[Freenet]] creator [[Ian Clarke (computer scientist)|Ian Clarke]], [[Steven Starr]] and Rob Kramer in 2000, in response to allegations that artists would not receive adequate compensation for their work without enforceable copyrights. Starr came up with the name.
In the FairShare system, the investor/patrons would provide [[venture capital]]. Clarke envisions that 45% of the money invested in a given artist would go directly to that artist, while another 45% would be given to previous investors. The remaining 10% would be kept by the maintainers of each FairShare service company.
In some ways this model is similar to a [[pyramid scheme]], but Clarke counters that a vital difference is that nobody would be promised a return on their investment. He argues that regardless of any profits, each patron would have the satisfaction of knowing that they supported an artist whose work they appreciate. Also, earlier investors would profit more, thus rewarding them for investing in artists before they became more popular. The early investors would serve a similar role to studios' talent scouts.
==See also== *[[Anti-copyright]] *[[Copynorms]] *[[Share-alike]] *[[Copyleft]] *[[Copyright-free]] *[[Creative Commons]] *[[File sharing]] :*[[Peer-to-peer]] *[[Gift economy]] *[[Fund and release]] *[[Open Music Model]] *[[Public domain]]
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070314205708/http://freenetproject.org/fairshare.html Ian Clarke's original essay on FairShare].
[[Category:Intellectual property law]]
